sn45.173:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four kinds of grasping.

sn45.173:1.3.eng: Grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.

sn45.173:1.4.eng: These are the four kinds of grasping.

sn45.173:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ upādānānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya …pe… ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.173:1.5.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these four kinds of grasping.”

sn45.174:1.3.pli: Abhijjhā kāyagantho, byāpādo kāyagantho, sīlabbataparāmāso kāyagantho, idaṃsaccābhiniveso kāyagantho—
sn45.174:1.3.eng: The personal ties to covetousness, ill will, misapprehension of precepts and observances, and the insistence that this is the only truth.

sn45.174:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, catunnaṃ ganthānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya …pe… ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.174:1.5.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these four ties.”

sn45.175:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these seven underlying tendencies.

sn45.175:1.3.pli: Kāmarāgānusayo, paṭighānusayo, diṭṭhānusayo, vicikicchānusayo, mānānusayo, bhavarāgānusayo, avijjānusayo—
sn45.175:1.3.eng: The underlying tendencies of sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire for continued existence, and ignorance.

sn45.175:1.4.eng: These are the seven underlying tendencies.

sn45.175:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, sattannaṃ anusayānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya …pe… ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.175:1.5.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these seven underlying tendencies.”

sn45.176:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn45.176:1.3.pli: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā,
sn45.176:1.3.eng: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn45.176:1.4.eng: Sounds known by the ear … Smells known by the nose …

sn45.176:1.6.pli: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṃhitā rajanīyā—
sn45.176:1.6.eng: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

sn45.176:1.7.eng: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

sn45.176:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ kāmaguṇānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya …pe… ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.176:1.8.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five kinds of sensual stimulation.”

sn45.177:1.3.eng: The hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.

sn45.177:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ nīvaraṇānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya …pe… ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.177:1.5.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five hindrances.”

sn45.178:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five grasping aggregates.

sn45.178:1.3.eng: The grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

sn45.178:1.4.eng: These are the five grasping aggregates.

sn45.178:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ upādānakkhandhānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya …pe… ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.178:1.5.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five grasping aggregates.”

sn45.179:1.3.eng: Substantialist view, doubt, misapprehension of precepts and observances, sensual desire, and ill will.

sn45.179:1.4.eng: These are the five lower fetters.

sn45.179:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya …pe… ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.179:1.5.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five lowers fetters.”

sn45.18:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca ānando āyasmā ca bhaddo pāṭaliputte viharanti kukkuṭārāme.
sn45.18:1.2.eng: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Bhadda were staying near Pāṭaliputta, in the Chicken Monastery.

sn45.18:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā bhaddo sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn45.18:1.3.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Bhadda came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn45.18:1.4.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā bhaddo āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.18:1.4.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda:

sn45.18:2.1.eng: “Reverend, they speak of this thing called ‘not the spiritual path’.

sn45.18:2.2.eng: What is not the spiritual path?”

sn45.18:2.4.pli: Bhaddako kho te, āvuso bhadda, ummaṅgo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
sn45.18:2.4.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question.

sn45.18:2.6.eng: ‘They speak of this thing called “not the spiritual path”.

sn45.18:2.7.eng: What is not the spiritual path?’”

sn45.18:2.9.pli: “Ayameva kho, āvuso, aṭṭhaṅgiko micchāmaggo abrahmacariyaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
sn45.18:2.9.eng: “What is not the spiritual path is simply the wrong eightfold path, that is:

sn45.18:2.10.eng: wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.”

sn45.180:1.3.eng: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

sn45.180:1.4.eng: These are the five higher fetters.

sn45.180:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo.
sn45.180:1.5.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

sn45.180:1.6.eng: What is the noble eightfold path?

sn45.180:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn45.180:1.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn45.180:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabboti.
sn45.180:1.8.eng: This is the noble eightfold path that should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.”

sn45.180:2.3.eng: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

sn45.180:2.4.eng: These are the five higher fetters.

sn45.180:2.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo.
sn45.180:2.5.eng: The noble eightfold path should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

sn45.180:2.6.eng: What is the noble eightfold path?

sn45.180:2.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ …
sn45.180:2.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which culminate in the removal of greed, hate, and delusion …”

sn45.180:2.8.eng: “… whose objective, destination, and culmination is freedom from death …”

sn45.180:2.9.eng: “… which slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment.

sn45.180:2.10.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ayaṃ ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo bhāvetabbo”ti.
sn45.180:2.10.eng: This is the noble eightfold path that should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.”

sn45.180:6.6.eng: The Linked Discourses on the Path is the first section.

sn45.19:1.2.eng: “Reverend, they speak of this thing called the ‘spiritual path’.

sn45.19:1.3.pli: Katamaṃ nu kho, āvuso, brahmacariyaṃ, katamaṃ brahmacariyapariyosānan”ti?
sn45.19:1.3.eng: What is the spiritual path? And what is the culmination of the spiritual path?”

sn45.19:1.5.pli: Bhaddako kho te, āvuso bhadda, ummaṅgo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
sn45.19:1.5.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question.

sn45.19:1.7.eng: ‘They speak of this thing called “the spiritual path”.

sn45.19:1.8.pli: Katamaṃ nu kho, āvuso, brahmacariyaṃ, katamaṃ brahmacariyapariyosānan’”ti?
sn45.19:1.8.eng: What is the spiritual path? And what is the culmination of the spiritual path?’”

sn45.19:1.10.pli: “Ayameva kho, āvuso, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo brahmacariyaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
sn45.19:1.10.eng: “The spiritual path is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.19:1.11.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.19:1.12.pli: Yo kho, āvuso, rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo—
sn45.19:1.12.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion:

sn45.19:1.13.eng: this is the culmination of the spiritual path.”

sn45.2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sakyesu viharati nagarakaṃ nāma sakyānaṃ nigamo.
sn45.2:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, where they have a town named Townsville.

sn45.2:1.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.2:1.3.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

sn45.2:1.4.eng: “Sir, good friends, companions, and associates are half the spiritual life.”

sn45.2:2.2.pli: Sakalamevidaṃ, ānanda, brahmacariyaṃ, yadidaṃ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā.
sn45.2:2.2.eng: Good friends, companions, and associates are the whole of the spiritual life.

sn45.2:2.3.pli: Kalyāṇamittassetaṃ, ānanda, bhikkhuno pāṭikaṅkhaṃ kalyāṇasahāyassa kalyāṇasampavaṅkassa—ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvessati, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkarissati.
sn45.2:2.3.eng: A mendicant with good friends, companions, and associates can expect to develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path.

sn45.2:3.1.pli: Kathañcānanda, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti?
sn45.2:3.1.eng: And how does a mendicant with good friends develop and cultivate the noble eightfold path?

sn45.2:3.2.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ;
sn45.2:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, which relies on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripens as letting go.

sn45.2:3.9.pli: sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn45.2:3.9.eng: right immersion, which relies on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripens as letting go.

sn45.2:3.10.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, bhikkhu kalyāṇamitto kalyāṇasahāyo kalyāṇasampavaṅko ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāveti, ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaroti.
sn45.2:3.10.eng: That’s how a mendicant with good friends develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path.

sn45.2:4.1.pli: Tadamināpetaṃ, ānanda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sakalamevidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, yadidaṃ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā.
sn45.2:4.1.eng: And here’s another way to understand how good friends are the whole of the spiritual life.

sn45.2:4.2.pli: Mamañhi, ānanda, kalyāṇamittaṃ āgamma jātidhammā sattā jātiyā parimuccanti; jarādhammā sattā jarāya parimuccanti; maraṇadhammā sattā maraṇena parimuccanti; sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā sattā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsehi parimuccanti.
sn45.2:4.2.eng: For, by relying on me as a good friend, sentient beings who are liable to rebirth, old age, and death, to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are freed from all these things.

sn45.2:4.3.pli: Iminā kho etaṃ, ānanda, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā sakalamevidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, yadidaṃ—kalyāṇamittatā kalyāṇasahāyatā kalyāṇasampavaṅkatā”ti.
sn45.2:4.3.eng: This is another way to understand how good friends are the whole of the spiritual life.”

sn45.20:1.2.eng: “Reverend, they speak of this thing called the ‘spiritual path’.

sn45.20:1.3.pli: Katamaṃ nu kho, āvuso, brahmacariyaṃ, katamo brahmacārī, katamaṃ brahmacariyapariyosānan”ti?
sn45.20:1.3.eng: What is the spiritual path? Who is someone on the spiritual path? And what is the culmination of the spiritual path?”

sn45.20:1.5.pli: Bhaddako kho te, āvuso bhadda, ummaṅgo, bhaddakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ, kalyāṇī paripucchā.
sn45.20:1.5.eng: Your approach and articulation are excellent, and it’s a good question. …

sn45.20:1.8.pli: Katamaṃ nu kho, āvuso, brahmacariyaṃ, katamo brahmacārī, katamaṃ brahmacariyapariyosānan’”ti?

sn45.20:1.10.pli: “Ayameva kho, āvuso, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo brahmacariyaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
sn45.20:1.10.eng: The spiritual path is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.20:1.11.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.20:1.12.pli: Yo kho, āvuso, iminā ariyena aṭṭhaṅgikena maggena samannāgato—
sn45.20:1.12.eng: Someone who possesses this noble eightfold path

sn45.20:1.13.eng: is called someone on the spiritual path.

sn45.20:1.14.pli: Yo kho, āvuso, rāgakkhayo dosakkhayo mohakkhayo—
sn45.20:1.14.eng: The ending of greed, hate, and delusion:

sn45.20:1.15.eng: this is the culmination of the spiritual path.”

sn45.21:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the wrong way and the right way.

sn45.21:1.4.eng: And what is the wrong way?

sn45.21:1.5.eng: It is wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

sn45.21:1.6.eng: This is called the wrong way.

sn45.21:1.7.eng: And what is the right way?

sn45.21:1.8.eng: It is right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.21:1.9.eng: This is called the right way.”

sn45.22:1.2.pli: “Akusale ca kho, bhikkhave, dhamme desessāmi, kusale ca dhamme.
sn45.22:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you skillful and unskillful qualities.

sn45.22:1.5.eng: They are wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

sn45.22:1.8.eng: They are right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.23:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the wrong practice and the right practice.

sn45.23:1.5.eng: It is wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

sn45.23:1.6.eng: This is called the wrong practice.

sn45.23:1.8.eng: It is right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.23:1.9.eng: This is called the right practice.”

sn45.24:1.2.pli: “Gihino vāhaṃ, bhikkhave, pabbajitassa vā micchāpaṭipadaṃ na vaṇṇemi.
sn45.24:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I don’t praise wrong practice for laypeople or renunciates.

sn45.24:1.3.pli: Gihi vā, bhikkhave, pabbajito vā micchāpaṭipanno micchāpaṭipattādhikaraṇahetu nārādhako hoti ñāyaṃ dhammaṃ kusalaṃ.
sn45.24:1.3.eng: Because of wrong practice, neither laypeople nor renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.

sn45.24:2.2.eng: It is wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

sn45.24:2.3.eng: This is called the wrong practice.

sn45.24:2.4.pli: Gihino vāhaṃ, bhikkhave, pabbajitassa vā micchāpaṭipadaṃ na vaṇṇemi.
sn45.24:2.4.eng: I don’t praise wrong practice for lay people or renunciates.

sn45.24:2.5.pli: Gihi vā, bhikkhave, pabbajito vā micchāpaṭipanno micchāpaṭipattādhikaraṇahetu nārādhako hoti ñāyaṃ dhammaṃ kusalaṃ.
sn45.24:2.5.eng: Because of wrong practice, neither laypeople nor renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.

sn45.24:3.1.pli: Gihino vāhaṃ, bhikkhave, pabbajitassa vā sammāpaṭipadaṃ vaṇṇemi.
sn45.24:3.1.eng: I praise right practice for laypeople and renunciates.

sn45.24:3.2.pli: Gihi vā, bhikkhave, pabbajito vā sammāpaṭipanno sammāpaṭipattādhikaraṇahetu ārādhako hoti ñāyaṃ dhammaṃ kusalaṃ.
sn45.24:3.2.eng: Because of right practice, both laypeople and renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.

sn45.24:3.4.eng: It is right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.24:3.5.eng: This is called the right practice.

sn45.24:3.6.pli: Gihino vāhaṃ, bhikkhave, pabbajitassa vā sammāpaṭipadaṃ vaṇṇemi.
sn45.24:3.6.eng: I praise right practice for laypeople and renunciates.

sn45.24:3.7.pli: Gihi vā, bhikkhave, pabbajito vā sammāpaṭipanno sammāpaṭipattādhikaraṇahetu ārādhako hoti ñāyaṃ dhammaṃ kusalan”ti.
sn45.24:3.7.eng: Because of right practice, both laypeople and renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.”

sn45.25:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you an untrue person and a true person.

sn45.25:1.4.eng: And what is an untrue person?

sn45.25:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, micchāsaṅkappo, micchāvāco, micchākammanto, micchāājīvo, micchāvāyāmo, micchāsati, micchāsamādhi—
sn45.25:1.5.eng: It’s someone who has wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

sn45.25:1.6.eng: This is called an untrue person.

sn45.25:2.1.eng: And what is a true person?

sn45.25:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sammādiṭṭhiko hoti, sammāsaṅkappo, sammāvāco, sammākammanto, sammāājīvo, sammāvāyāmo, sammāsati, sammāsamādhi—
sn45.25:2.2.eng: It’s someone who has right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.25:2.3.eng: This is called a true person.”

sn45.26:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you an untrue person and an even more untrue person,

sn45.26:1.3.pli: Sappurisañca vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi sappurisena sappurisatarañca.
sn45.26:1.3.eng: a true person and an even truer person.

sn45.26:1.5.eng: And what is an untrue person?

sn45.26:1.6.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco micchādiṭṭhiko hoti …pe… micchāsamādhi—
sn45.26:1.6.eng: It’s someone who has wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.

sn45.26:1.7.eng: This is called an untrue person.

sn45.26:2.1.eng: And what is an even more untrue person?

sn45.26:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco micchādiṭṭhiko hoti …pe… micchāsamādhi, micchāñāṇī, micchāvimutti—
sn45.26:2.2.eng: It’s someone who has wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong immersion, wrong knowledge, and wrong freedom.

sn45.26:2.3.eng: This is called an even more untrue person.

sn45.26:3.1.eng: And what is a true person?

sn45.26:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sammādiṭṭhiko hoti …pe… sammāsamādhi—
sn45.26:3.2.eng: It’s someone who has right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.26:3.3.eng: This is called a true person.

sn45.26:4.1.eng: And what is an even truer person?

sn45.26:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sammādiṭṭhiko hoti …pe… sammāsamādhi, sammāñāṇī, sammāvimutti—
sn45.26:4.2.eng: It’s someone who has right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.

sn45.26:4.3.eng: This is called an even truer person.”

sn45.27:1.2.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kumbho anādhāro suppavattiyo hoti, sādhāro duppavattiyo hoti;
sn45.27:1.2.eng: “A pot without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.

sn45.27:1.3.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, cittaṃ anādhāraṃ suppavattiyaṃ hoti, sādhāraṃ duppavattiyaṃ hoti.
sn45.27:1.3.eng: In the same way, a mind without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.

sn45.27:1.4.eng: And what’s the stand for the mind?

sn45.27:1.5.eng: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

sn45.27:1.6.eng: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.27:1.7.eng: This is the stand for the mind.

sn45.27:1.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kumbho anādhāro suppavattiyo hoti, sādhāro duppavattiyo hoti;
sn45.27:1.8.eng: A pot without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.

sn45.27:1.9.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, cittaṃ anādhāraṃ suppavattiyaṃ hoti, sādhāraṃ duppavattiyaṃ hotī”ti.
sn45.27:1.9.eng: In the same way, a mind without a stand is easy to overturn, but if it has a stand it’s hard to overturn.”
